entry.title: Combined summary - getmemorypool BIP process
entry.summary: Several discussions were held concerning the limitations of using HTTP and JSON-RPC as a client-server model. Stefan Thomas proposed using http keep-alive combined with an event system to create an update function for JSON-RPC, similar to how web chat applications work. However, it was pointed out that HTTP and JSON-RPC are client-server models, which makes it impractical for the server to make calls to the client.Gavin Andresen initially shared this view but was corrected by another participant who cited section 2.1 of the JSON-RPC spec, which shows that it is possible to use JSON-RPC over other transports besides HTTP. Geir Harald Hansen reported a race condition in long polling currently implemented in pools. He suggested adding "longpollid" in long poll responses and including the last seen longpollid in future long poll requests so the server can see if the client has missed any block changes. Another useful value in the getmemorypool response would be "height" so that the miner can include the correct height in the coinbase. Hansen also suggested explaining how target vs. fulltarget works. Some participants suggested making some things optional for a client to implement safely, which needs some way for clients to communicate capabilities to the server. Finally, it was discussed that "noncerange" is of limited use and there's a good chance of getting the endianness wrong.The Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) has released a draft of its "getmemorypool" protocol, which is designed to improve the memory pool process. This new system will enable miners to more efficiently select transactions to include in the next block by providing them with details about unconfirmed transactions. The "getmemorypool" protocol will also enhance the security of the network by allowing users to monitor and track any suspicious transactions. Stefan Thomas initiated a separate discussion regarding the use of polling model in BIP to request new work from a pool at intervals. He suggested specifying a version of the API supporting long-polling, but it was pointed out that HTTP and JSON-RPC are client-server models, which makes it impractical for the server to make calls to the client. Additionally, many clients cannot listen on WAN ports at all, making it difficult to expect them to run their own JSON-RPC server.There is no explicit standard way to do S->C JSON-RPC. The JSON-RPC 1.0 spec does not require a certain transport protocol, and many libraries come with TCP socket support out of the box. However, plain TCP sockets have no standardized authentication mechanism, so an extra RPC call auth("username", "password") needs to be added. BitcoinJS currently implements plain TCP sockets and detects whether an incoming connection is HTTP or raw JSON-RPC based on the first character. JSON-RPC over TLS sockets, challenge-response authentication, and TLS client handshake (certificate authentication) are planned features to be added to the JSON-RPC API in the future. On the other hand, HTTP Keep-Alive works, but it's not very widely supported among client libraries, and HTTP isn't really made for this type of thing.Geir Harald Hansen has proposed a solution to the race condition in long polling, suggesting adding "longpollid" in long poll responses, which should be included by the client in future long poll requests. He also proposes including the "height" value in the getmemorypool response to help miners include the correct height in the coinbase. Geir thinks some features should be optional for a client to implement and suggests adding an optional "servercapabilities" key on the server side, the value being a space-delimited list of what's supported by the server.The draft proposal for the "getmemorypool" protocol has the potential to improve the efficiency and security of the Bitcoin network. Feedback and comments can be provided on the BIP's official wiki page.The Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) has released a draft of its "getmemorypool" protocol designed to improve the memory pool process, enabling miners to more efficiently select transactions to include in the next block. This new protocol will enhance the security of the network by allowing users to monitor and track any suspicious transactions. The "getmemorypool" protocol will create a separate memory pool for each miner, allowing them to view all available transactions and select the ones they wish to include in their block, reducing orphaned blocks produced by miners. The new protocol will allow miners to specify certain transaction types that they wish to prioritize when selecting which transactions to include in their block, ensuring that high-priority transactions are processed quickly.The context also contains a link to a page about virtualization and cloud management using capacity planning. It highlights how cloud computing uses virtualization to deliver computing as a service. Additionally, the context provides information about the Bitcoin-development mailing list with a link to sign up for it.
